translated: The Questions of King Milinda
The Great Chapter
The Questions of Vīmaṁsana
The King said:
“Revered Nāgasena, will you hold a discussion with me?”

original: “Sace tvaṁ, mahārāja, paṇḍitavādaṁ sallapissasi sallapissāmi, sace pana rājavādaṁ sallapissasi na sallapissāmī”ti.
analyzed: sace tva mahā rāja paṇḍita vādam sallapissasi sallapissāmi sace pana rāja vādam sallapissasi na sallapissāmi iti
translated: “If you, sire, will hold a discussion in the manner of the wise, I will do so; but if you will hold a discussion in the manner of kings, I will not.”

analyzed: katha bhante nāgasena paṇḍitā sat lapanti iti
translated: “How, revered sir, do the wise hold a discussion?”

original: “Paṇḍitānaṁ kho, mahārāja, sallāpe āveṭhanampi kayirati, nibbeṭhanampi kayirati,
analyzed: paṇḍitānam kho mahā rāja sallāpe āveṭhanam pi kayirati nibbeṭhanam pi kayirati
translated: “In the case of the wise, sire, there is a turning back, there is a turning away,

original: niggahopi kayirati, paṭikammampi kayirati, vissāsopi kayirati, paṭivissāsopi kayirati,
analyzed: niggahaḥ api kayirati paṭikammam api kayirati vissāsaḥ api kayirati paṭivissāsaḥ api kayirati
translated: there is a seizing, there is a counteracting, there is a trusting, there is a counter-trusting,

original: na ca tena paṇḍitā kuppanti, evaṁ kho, mahārāja, paṇḍitā sallapantī”ti.
analyzed: na ca tena paṇḍitā kuppanti evam kho mahā rāja paṇḍitā sallapanti iti
translated: and yet the wise are not angry on that account. That is how the wise hold a discussion.”

analyzed: katham pana bhante rājāno sallapanti iti
translated: “But how, revered sir, do kings hold a discussion?”

original: “Rājāno kho, mahārāja, sallāpe ekaṁ vatthuṁ paṭijānanti, yo taṁ vatthuṁ vilometi, tassa daṇḍaṁ āṇāpenti ‘imassa daṇḍaṁ paṇethā’ti, evaṁ kho, mahārāja, rājāno sallapantī”ti.
analyzed: rājānaḥ kho mahā rāja sallāpe ekam vatthum paṭijānanti yaḥ tam vatthum vilometi tassa daṇḍam āṇāpenti imassa daṇḍam paṇetha ati evam kho mahā rāja rājānaḥ sallapanti iti
translated: “Great king, when kings talk together, they admit a point. If anyone contradicts that point, they order a penalty for him, ‘Punish him thus and so.’ That is how kings talk together.”

original: “Paṇḍitavādāhaṁ, bhante, sallapissāmi, no rājavādaṁ, vissaṭṭho bhadanto sallapatu
analyzed: paṇḍita vādā āha bhante sallapissāmi no rāja vāda vissaṭṭhaḥ bhadantaḥ sallapatu
translated: “Venerable sir, I will talk as a wise man, not as a king. Let the reverend one talk as a wise man.

original: yathā bhikkhunā vā sāmaṇerena vā upāsakena vā ārāmikena vā saddhiṁ sallapati, evaṁ
analyzed: yathā bhikkhunā vā sāmaṇerena vā upāsakena vā ārāmikena vā saddhim sallapati eva
translated: Let the reverend one talk as he would talk with a bhikkhu, a male novice, a female novice, or a monastery attendant.

analyzed: vissaṭṭhaḥ bhadantaḥ sallapatu mā bhāyatu iti
translated: Let the reverend one talk as a wise man. Let him not be afraid.”
“Very well, great king,” the elder agreed.
The king said,
“Venerable Nāgasena, I will ask you a question.”
“Ask, great king.”
“I have asked you, venerable sir.”
“I have answered, great king.”
“But what have you answered, venerable sir?”

analyzed: kim pana mahā rāja tayā pucchitanti
translated: “But what have you asked, great king?”
The third section for recitation on interrogation is finished.
